qas.question: As immunosuppression goes up in tuberculosis cases, what risk rises with it?
What disease has a similar relationship as TB does between reactivation and immunosuppression?
If you'd been diagnosed with tuberculosis in 1995, how great a chance would you have faced of dying from it?
In what year did the risk of dying from TB reach half what it was in 1995?
New studies have found that half of reactivation cases of tuberculosis might actually be due to what other "re-" word?
Reactivation is caused by what disease?
What is the risk of reactivation in someone who only has M. tuberculosis?
What was the chance of death from HIV in 2008?
When did scientists begin to suspect reinfection was worse than previously thought?
What methods have recent studies used to examine HIV strains?

context: The risk of <a0_0>reactivation<a0_0/> increases with immunosuppression, such as that caused by infection with <a1_0><b5_0>HIV<b5_0/><a1_0/>. In people coinfected with M. tuberculosis and HIV, the risk of reactivation increases to <b6_0>10% per year<b6_0/>. Studies using <b9_0>DNA fingerprinting<b9_0/> of M. tuberculosis strains have shown <a4_0>reinfection<a4_0/> contributes more substantially to recurrent TB than previously thought, with estimates that it might account for more than 50% of reactivated cases in areas where TB is common. The chance of death from a case of tuberculosis is about <b7_0>4%<b7_0/> as of <a3_0><b8_0>2008<b8_0/><a3_0/>, down from <a2_0>8%<a2_0/> in 1995.
